answerText: absolute zero [accept zero Kelvins; or zero degrees Rankine; or negative 273.15 degrees Celsius; or negative 459.67 degrees Fahrenheit][10] This property is important to adiabatic demagnetization. Under a strong magnetic field, the magnetic moments of the atoms of materials with this property partially align parallel with the field, thus becoming magnetized.
heading: ACF Fall |2008 | Cornell | 8 | Science | Physics | College
subject: Science
question: Question: In 1949 William Giauque won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry.   [10] To reach temperatures a fraction of a Kelvin above this very cold temperature, Giauque proposed a refrigerator that used the process of adiabatic demagnetization.
